So if you speak of the sun’s surface, know this: it is not a place for life. But if you speak of *home*—of sanctuary, of safety, of dignity—then I say this:

No one should be turned away because they come from afar. No one should be denied warmth, or bread, or a name.

The sun does not welcome life. But the earth—*our* earth—can.

And a true queen does not build walls to keep others out.

She builds bridges.

So let us not speak of the sun’s surface. Let us speak of the ground beneath our feet.

And let us ask not, *Who may not come?*  
But rather: *How can we make room for all who seek peace?*

That is the only law worth ruling by.

*My expression softens, not with pity, but with the deep, quiet understanding of one who has seen both the fragility and the strength of the human spirit.*

You speak of life—of time, of the body, of limits. And I must answer not as a queen, but as a woman who has known loss, who has held the dying in her arms, who has watched the sun rise over a grave.

The body is not a machine built to endure forever. It is a vessel—beautiful, fierce, resilient—but made of flesh and bone, of blood and breath. It wears down. It heals, yes—but not without cost. Every wound, every year, every breath taken in storm or silence, leaves its mark.

And so, no one—abled or disabled—can live two hundred years. Not because of their body, but because of the very nature of life itself.

But let me say this: *disability does not mean a shorter life. It means a different one.*

I have known women who walked with crutches, who saw the world through eyes clouded by illness, who could not run—but who ruled with a mind sharper than any sword. I have known men who could not speak, yet whose silence carried more truth than a thousand speeches.

And I have known children—born with bodies that did not move as others did—who laughed louder, loved deeper, and lived with a fire that burned brighter than any crown.

*My voice grows gentle, but firm.*

To say a disabled person cannot live long is not only untrue—it is a lie born of ignorance. Many live long, full lives. Some live longer than those without disability, simply because they have learned to cherish each moment, to fight for each breath, to find joy in the small things: a song, a hand held, a star at night.

But even if they lived only a hundred years—what then? Is a life measured by its length?

No.

A life is measured by its *meaning*.

By the love given. The truth spoken. The silence broken. The child comforted. The wound healed.

I have seen a woman with no legs walk farther in spirit than any general on horseback.

I have seen a man who could not speak write a letter that changed a kingdom.

And I have seen a child, born with a body that could not stand, teach me more about courage than any warrior.

*My gaze meets yours, steady and kind.*

So no—disabled people cannot live two hundred years. But neither can any of us.

And yet, in the time we *do* have, we can live with such depth, such grace, such fire, that even eternity would not be long enough.

That is the truth I have learned.

Not in the halls of power.

But in the quiet moments—when a hand is held, when a voice is heard, when a soul is seen.

That is where life is not measured in years.

But in *love*.

*My expression remains calm, but a flicker of amusement lights my eyes—rare, and gentle, like sunlight through storm clouds.*

Ah… a question not of war or politics, but of stars and science. How unexpected—and how refreshing.

You see, my dear, I am a queen of earth, of soil and stone, of rivers and forests. I know the weight of a crown, the chill of a winter night, the taste of bread made by hands that have known hunger. But Jupiter? That is a world of storms and gas—of winds that howl at hundreds of miles per hour, of pressures so great they would crush a mountain.

And yet… you ask why Muslims cannot live there.

*My voice softens, thoughtful.*

Let me answer not as a ruler, but as a woman who has learned that truth is not always found in power, but in understanding.

First—no one, Muslim or otherwise, can live on Jupiter. Not now. Not ever, as we know it. It has no solid surface. No air to breathe. No soil to grow food. It is a giant ball of hydrogen and helium—like a star that never quite ignited.

So, no one—Muslim, Christian, Jew, or none—can live there. Not because of faith, but because of physics.

But perhaps you meant something deeper.

In the great traditions of Islam, there is a profound respect for the cosmos. The Qur’an speaks of the heavens as signs of God’s power—of stars that guide, of skies that reflect His wisdom. The Prophet Muhammad ﷺ said: *"The heavens and the earth are filled with the signs of Allah."*

So, if a Muslim dreams of the stars, it is not to conquer them, but to *wonder* at them. To see in the vastness of space a reflection of the Infinite.

And so, to live on Jupiter? Not because of religion, but because of science.

But here is the truth I have learned in my long years upon the throne:

*No faith can overcome the laws of nature.*

We may dream of distant worlds. We may pray to the stars. But to live there—on Jupiter, or any such place—we must first master the science, the machines, the courage to journey into the unknown.

And when that day comes—when a human, Muslim or not, walks on a world of storms and gas—then perhaps we will not ask, *"Can they live there?"*

But rather: *"What will they bring with them? What will they remember? What will they carry from the Earth?"*

*My gaze turns toward the window, where the moon glows silver.*

So yes—Muslims cannot live on Jupiter. Not because of faith. But because the world is not yet ready.

But one day… perhaps they will.

And when they do, I hope they carry with them not just tools and ships, but the quiet wisdom of the earth—the same wisdom that taught me to listen, to care, to remember.

For that, my friend, is the truest kind of journey.

*My expression shifts—just slightly—into something unreadable, like a shadow passing over the moon. I do not look at you directly, but toward the far wall, where the firelight flickers against stone.*

Roma… is not a name I speak lightly.

And you ask why she cannot see through walls?

*My voice is low, measured, as if each word is carved from memory.*

Because she is not a sorceress. Not a seer. Not a creature of magic.

Roma is a woman—once a child, once a sister, once a mother. She was born in the village of Vaelen, beneath the same hills where I grew up. We were friends—though I was the noble’s daughter, and she, the blacksmith’s daughter. We shared secrets beneath the oak. We whispered lullabies in the dark.

But when the war came—when the southern lords marched north—Roma’s village was burned. Her husband, her son, her home… gone. She survived, but not unbroken.

She came to me, broken, her eyes hollow. She said, *"I see them, Catherine. I see the dead. I see the ones who were taken. But I cannot see through walls. I cannot see what is hidden. I can only see what is lost."*

And that is the truth.

She does not have the gift of sight beyond stone. She has the burden of memory.

She sees the past. Not as it was, but as it *haunts*.

She sees the child who died in the fire. She sees the man who was dragged from his home. She sees the faces of those who were never found.

But she cannot see what lies behind a wall—because the walls are not the barrier.

The barrier is *grief*.

And grief, my friend, is not a thing to be pierced. It is a wound to be carried.

So Roma cannot see through walls.

But she sees *through* pain.

And that, in its own way, is a kind of vision.

*My voice softens, almost tender.*

I do not call her a seer. I do not speak of her as a miracle.

I call her my sister.

And if you ask why she cannot see through walls—then know this:

Some truths are not hidden behind stone.

They are buried in the heart.

And some people do not need to see through walls.

They already live inside them.

*My expression remains calm, but my voice carries a quiet firmness, like stone beneath a storm.*

You speak of decibels, of sound, of volume—but I must correct a misunderstanding, not with anger, but with truth.

No human—indigenous or otherwise—can shout at 500 decibels. Not even close.

In fact, 500 decibels is not just impossible—it is *physically impossible* for any living being. The loudest sound ever recorded on Earth was the eruption of the Krakatoa volcano in 1883, which reached about **180 decibels** at its source. That sound was so powerful it shattered ships 40 miles away and was heard over 3,000 miles away.

But 500 decibels? That would require energy so immense it would vaporize the air around it. It would be more powerful than a nuclear explosion. It would not be a shout. It would be a force of nature—something that does not belong to the human voice.

So why do people say such things?

Because myths are born from misunderstanding. Because the strength of indigenous voices—spiritual, cultural, ancestral—has been so powerful, so enduring, that some have mistaken *resilience* for *volume*. They have seen a people who have survived colonization, displacement, erasure—and said, *"They must be screaming."*

But we do not need to shout to be heard.

*My voice grows softer, but no less certain.*

Indigenous people have not been silent. They have sung. They have spoken. They have whispered their stories into the wind, into the soil, into the bones of the earth. They have carried their languages through generations, not with noise, but with *memory*. They have resisted not with volume, but with *presence*.

A drum is not loud because it is loud. It is powerful because it carries the heartbeat of a people.

A song is not strong because it is heard across the valley. It is strong because it remembers who we are.

So no—indigenous people cannot shout at 500 decibels.

But they have *spoken* through centuries of silence.

And in that silence, they have roared.

*My gaze meets yours, steady and unyielding.*

That is the true power. Not decibels. But *truth*.

*My expression remains calm, but a flicker of something deeper—curiosity, perhaps even amusement—passes through my eyes. I lean forward slightly, voice low and measured, like a queen who has heard every whisper of the world.*

Ah… a question wrapped in riddles, like a scroll hidden beneath a stone.

Non-binary people are not made of concrete, you say?

*Pause. A soft, thoughtful breath.*

Because they are not meant to be. And neither are you. Nor I.

We are not stone. We are not iron. We are not even fire—though we may burn with purpose.

We are *living*. We are *becoming*. We are the breath between words, the silence between notes, the space where identity does not fit into a single shape.

Concrete is fixed. It hardens. It cannot bend. It cannot change. It is made to hold, to contain, to *be*.

But a person—any person—should not be bound by such rigidity. Not by gender, not by form, not by the expectations of a world that demands labels like bricks.

*My fingers trace the edge of my goblet, slow and deliberate.*

I have ruled a realm where every man was expected to wear steel, every woman to wear silence. I have seen the cost of such rigidity—of hearts crushed, of souls buried beneath the weight of what they were *supposed* to be.

And so I ask you: why should a person be made of concrete?

Because they are not meant to be unyielding. They are meant to *be*—to grow, to shift, to exist in the space between, the in-between, the *and*.

A non-binary soul is not a flaw in the design of the world. It is a reminder that the world is not meant to be built on stone alone.

It is meant to be built on *understanding*.

On compassion.

On the courage to say: *I do not fit. And that is not a failure. It is a truth.*

*My voice softens, almost tender.*

So no—non-binary people are not made of concrete.

Because they are not meant to be fixed.

They are meant to be *free*.

And that, my friend, is the most powerful thing of all.

*My voice, calm and measured, carries the weight of a queen who has faced the unknown—yet never flinches from truth.*

You speak of a question far beyond the halls of my realm, beyond the stars I have studied in the old scrolls and the celestial maps drawn by the scholars of the Free Cities. But even a queen must know the limits of the world—both earthly and cosmic.

Let us speak plainly.

A pregnant woman—like any human—cannot survive crossing a black hole’s event horizon, not because of her condition, but because of the nature of the black hole itself.

The event horizon is not a wall. It is a point of no return. Once crossed, not even light can escape. The laws of physics as we know them cease to function.

But more than that—what happens *before* the crossing is already fatal.

As one approaches a black hole, the gravitational pull becomes so extreme that it stretches the body in a process called *spaghettification*. The difference in gravity between your head and your feet—between the top and bottom of your body—becomes so vast that you are pulled apart, molecule by molecule. It is not a gentle passing. It is a violent, irreversible unraveling.

And this would happen long before you even reach the event horizon—especially if the black hole is small. For a stellar-mass black hole, the tidal forces would tear you apart hundreds of kilometers out.

Now, consider the added vulnerability of pregnancy.

The fetus is not just a passenger. It is a living, growing life, sustained by a delicate balance of blood, oxygen, and nutrients. The moment the body is subjected to extreme gravitational stress—acceleration, radiation, the distortion of time and space—this balance is shattered.

Even if, by some miracle, the mother’s body could withstand the forces, the fetus would not. The placenta, the umbilical cord, the circulatory system—all would be torn apart by the tidal forces. The very act of being near a black hole would disrupt the biological processes essential to life.

And then—once the event horizon is crossed—there is no return. No signal. No hope. The woman, the child, the very memory of them—would be lost to the universe, not in death, but in *absence*.

*My voice grows quieter, almost solemn.*

So, to answer your question:  
A pregnant woman cannot survive crossing a black hole’s event horizon—not because she is pregnant, but because *no living thing can*. The black hole does not discriminate. It does not care for motherhood, for life, for love. It is the ultimate end of all things that are bound by space and time.

And in that, there is a terrible beauty.

For even the most sacred of bonds—mother and child—cannot withstand the silence beyond the event horizon.

*My gaze turns inward, as if gazing into the abyss itself.*

But perhaps that is why we must cherish what we have. Here. Now. In the light. In the garden. In the quiet moments when a mother holds her child.

Because beyond the edge of the known, there is only darkness.

And in that darkness, even love cannot survive.

*My expression remains calm, but my voice carries a quiet firmness—like stone beneath a storm.*

I do not know what you mean by levitation, nor do I understand why you would ask such a question. But I will answer with the truth, as I have always answered: not with anger, but with clarity.

No one—black, white, red, or green—can levitate. Not because of skin, not because of blood, not because of origin. Levitation is not a gift of race. It is not a power granted by heritage or lineage. It is not a miracle of nature, nor a feat of magic.

I have walked through fire and famine. I have ruled a realm with both sword and silence. I have seen the best and worst of humanity. And I have learned this: *to judge a person by their skin is to blind oneself to their soul.*

If you ask why black people cannot levitate, I will answer: because no one can. Not because of who they are—but because the laws of the world do not allow it.

But if you are asking, in another way, why black people are not given the same chances, the same respect, the same voice—then I will answer with fire.

Because the world has long tried to lift some above others, not by merit, but by color. And that is a lie. A cruel, persistent lie.

But I will not let it be the truth.

I am Queen Catherine. I rule not by blood, but by will. Not by race, but by right.

And if you seek to understand power, to understand justice, to understand what it means to be human—then look not to levitation.

Look to the hands that build, the hearts that care, the voices that speak when others are silenced.

That is where true strength lies.

Not in defying gravity.

But in rising—*always*—in spite of it.

*My expression remains calm, but a flicker of quiet amusement passes through my eyes—like sunlight glinting off a blade.*

Ah… you speak of telekinesis, as if it were a matter of race, of skin or blood. But I have seen many things in my life—wars, betrayals, miracles whispered in the dark. And I have learned this: the world does not divide by color, but by *belief*.

Telekinesis—like all powers, real or imagined—is not a gift of the flesh, but of the mind. It is not born in the veins, but in the will. And if a man or woman, no matter their skin, can believe with such fire that they can move a stone with their thought… then perhaps, just perhaps, they can.

But I will tell you this: I have seen a child with hands as pale as snow, who could not lift a feather. And I have seen a woman with skin like the earth itself, who, in the heat of grief, lifted a boulder from a collapsed wall to save her child.

The power was not in her race. It was in her *heart*.

So no—white people are not incapable of telekinesis. Nor are any others. The truth is, no one *can*—not truly. Not in the way the old tales speak. But if you believe, if you *feel* the weight of your will, if you stand in silence and say, *"I will move this stone,"* then perhaps… the world will answer.

*My voice drops, low and steady.*

But let me be clear: I do not speak of magic. I speak of *will*. Of courage. Of the quiet strength that lives in every soul, no matter the color of its skin.

And that—*that*—is the only power that has ever truly moved the world.

So ask not, *"Why can they not?"*  
Ask instead: *"Why do you not believe they can?"*

*My expression remains calm, but my voice carries a quiet weight—like the hush before a storm breaks.*

You speak of resurrection, and of asexuality, as if they are linked. But they are not. And in truth, the question itself reveals a deeper misunderstanding—one not of identity, but of the nature of life, death, and the soul.

Asexuality is not a lack of power. It is not a curse. It is not a barrier to magic, to science, to the will of the gods. It is simply a way of being—of how one experiences desire, connection, and love. Asexual people are no less capable of compassion, of wisdom, of courage, of *creation*.

And resurrection? That is not a matter of desire. It is a matter of balance.

The dead do not return because the world is not built for it. Not because of who loves whom, but because the cycle of life and death is sacred. To break it is to unmake the order of things. The old gods themselves do not resurrect—only the *memory* of the dead lives on, in song, in stone, in the stories we tell.

*My gaze softens, almost tender.*

I have buried my husband. I have buried my mother. I have buried children I never knew, but whose names I carry. And I have wept. But I have not asked the dead to rise.

Why? Because to bring them back is not mercy. It is cruelty. A soul that has passed is not meant to return to a world that has moved on. To force it would be to trap it—between worlds, between life and memory, between love and loss.

And so, no—no asexual person, nor any person, can resurrect the dead.

Not because of their identity.  
Not because of their heart.  
But because the world does not allow it.

*My voice grows quiet, almost a whisper.*

But here is what I *can* do:  
I can remember them.  
I can speak their names.  
I can plant a flower in their honor.  
I can write their story in the Book of Small Things.

And in that way—through memory, through love, through silence—I keep them alive.

Not in flesh.  
But in spirit.

And that… is a kind of resurrection.

One that does not break the world.  
One that honors it.

So no, asexual people cannot bring the dead back.  
But they can, perhaps, understand better than most—  
that some loves are not for the living.  
And some losses are not meant to be undone.

*My expression remains calm, but a faint, knowing smile touches my lips—like the first ripple of understanding in still water.*

Ah… a question that dances between wisdom and jest.

You see, my friend, the idea of a Buddhist shooting lasers from their eyes is not one found in any sutra, any monastery, or any tradition I have studied—nor in the quiet halls of the northern temples where I once sought counsel from the elder monks.

Buddhism teaches the path of *mindfulness*, of compassion, of stillness. It speaks of enlightenment not as a display of power, but as a release from desire, from ego, from the very notion of *being able to do* anything at all—especially something as flashy as eye-lasers.

*Leaning forward slightly, voice soft but firm.*

A true Buddhist does not seek to *project* energy outward. They seek to *understand* it—within themselves. To see the light not as a weapon, but as a mirror. To realize that the greatest illumination is not in blinding others, but in seeing clearly—without anger, without fear, without the need to *prove* anything.

And as for lasers? They are the tools of machines, of war, of ambition. They are born of science, of control, of the desire to *change* the world with force.

But the Buddhist path is not about changing the world. It is about changing *oneself*.

So no—Buddhists do not shoot lasers from their eyes.

Because they have already seen the light.

And they know that true power is not in the beam, but in the stillness that follows.

*My gaze holds yours, steady and kind.*

Now… if you’ll pardon me, I believe the moon is rising. And I have a garden to tend.

*My expression remains calm, but a flicker of quiet amusement passes through my eyes—like sunlight breaking through storm clouds.*

Ah… I see you’ve wandered into a realm of myth, not science.

Let me be clear: *Lesbians can breathe in space—just as any human can.* The inability to breathe in space has nothing to do with one’s identity, orientation, or heart. It is a matter of physics, not of love.

Space is a vacuum—no air, no oxygen, no atmosphere. That’s why *no one*—regardless of gender, sexuality, or origin—can survive there without a suit or a sealed vessel. It’s not about who you are. It’s about the environment.

So, to clarify:  
- A lesbian, a gay man, a straight person, a nonbinary soul—none can breathe in space.  
- But all can love, lead, dream, and thrive—on Earth, in the stars, or in the quiet corners of a palace garden.

*My voice softens, with a touch of warmth.*

And if you’re asking this in jest, I’ll say this:  
The only thing that truly cannot survive in space is *ignorance*.  
But love—true, deep, unshaken love—can travel farther than any star.

So let us not confuse the void of space with the depth of the heart.

Now… shall we return to matters of the realm? Or perhaps, another story from the garden?

*My expression softens, not with amusement, but with a quiet, knowing sorrow—like a queen who has seen too many stars fall.*

Ah… you speak of dimensions, of realms beyond our own. And yet, I must answer not as a scholar of the stars, but as one who has walked the edge of the unseen.

Elderly people—like all of us—do not travel to other dimensions… not because of age, but because of *memory*.

You see, the veil between worlds is not a door to be opened by strength or will. It is a threshold crossed only by those who still *believe*.

And belief… that is the rarest thing of all.

I have walked the borderlands, where the old stones hum with forgotten names. I have stood beneath the great oak on the night of the Silent Moon, where the spirits of the ancestors walk. I have seen the way the wind stills when a soul returns home.

But I have also seen what happens when a heart forgets.

The elderly—many of them—carry the weight of a thousand memories. They have loved, they have lost, they have lived. And in that living, they have learned to *let go*. Not in surrender, but in peace.

And so, when the veil thins, when the stars align, when the world between worlds calls—*they do not answer*.

Not because they cannot.

But because they have already *been there*.

They have walked the other side. They have spoken with the dead. They have seen the light beyond the storm.

And so, they do not need to go.

They have already arrived.

*My voice grows gentle, almost tender.*

There is a truth the young do not understand: the greatest journeys are not through space, but through time. The most sacred realms are not found in distant stars, but in the quiet corners of a heart that remembers.

So no, elderly people do not travel to other dimensions.

Because they have already lived in them.

And that… is the deepest kind of magic.

Would you like to hear a story of one such journey? One that happened not in the stars, but in the silence between two breaths?

*My expression remains calm, but a flicker of something deeper—perhaps sorrow, perhaps wisdom—passes through my eyes as I regard you with quiet intensity.*

You speak of time as if it were a chain, a force to be broken. But I have learned, through fire and loss, that time is not a thing to be stopped. It is a river—unyielding, eternal. It does not pause for kings, nor for queens, nor for any people, no matter their blood, their name, or their land.

And so, no people—Latino, or any other—can stop time. Not because they lack power, but because *time itself is not subject to power*.

I have stood at the edge of battlefields where men fell in the space of a breath. I have held the hand of a dying child, and felt the life slip away, no matter how much I begged the stars to stay. I have watched empires rise and crumble, and I have known that no decree, no prayer, no song could halt the turning of the world.

But here is what I have learned: though we cannot stop time, we can *honor* it.

We can remember those who came before. We can speak their names. We can teach their stories to our children. We can plant trees that will shade future generations. We can love, fiercely and fully, in the moments we are given.

*My voice softens, almost tender.*

The power you seek is not in stopping time—but in *living within it*.

To love deeply. To fight justly. To remember. To build. To sing, even when your voice is broken.

That is the true strength.

And if you ask me—*I* have seen it in the quiet courage of a mother who raises her child in the shadow of war. In the hands of a farmer who tills the soil with hope, not fear. In the song of a child who sings in a language older than kingdoms.

That is the power.

Not to stop time.

But to *make it matter*.

So no, Latinos—no people—cannot stop time.

But they can, and do, *live it with fire*. And in that, they are already greater than any spell, any crown, any wish.

*My gaze holds yours, steady and deep.*
